metadata.title: UMAP for Data Integration. Graph-based Single Cell Omics… | by Nikolay Oskolkov | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: This is the twentieth article from the column Mathematical Statistics and Machine Learning for Life Sciences where I try to explain some mysterious analytical techniques used in Bioinformatics and…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Mathematical Statistics and Machine Learning for Life Sciences

all_paragraphs: This is the twentieth article from the column Mathematical Statistics and Machine Learning for Life Sciences where I try to explain some mysterious analytical techniques used in Bioinformatics and Computational Biology in a simple way. Data integration is an important next step for improving analysis accuracy by utilizing synergistic effects via combining multiple sources of information. In Computational Biology and Biomedicine, data integration is making particular advances in Single Cell research area. Last year, Nature recognized Single Cell Multimodal Omics Integration as a method of the year 2019. In this article, I will demonstrate how one can perform graph based across modalities integration of single cell Omics (scOmics) data by using graph intersection approach with Igraph and UMAP.

When combining data originating from different statistical distributions, it is probably not a good idea to simply concatenate them together without taking into account their individual distributions as some of them might be of binary, categorical or continuous nature. Working with scOmics data one often deals with continuous scRNAseq (transcriptomics) / scProteomics (proteomics) and binary scBSseq (methylation) / scATAseq (open chromatin region) data. Suppose the individual data types are capable of distinguishing cells from sick and healthy individuals with an accuracy of 78%, 83% and 75% (the numbers are made up). Then, one expectation from combining the multiple scOmics together would be a boost in prediction accuracy (e.g. up to 96%) due to reduction of technology-specific noise and enhancing the consistent across scOmics signal.

There can be different approaches to combining the individual scOmics. One possible way could be converting the scOmics into a common non-parametric space where they loose the memory about their technology of origin. This is how e.g. Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) are capable of collapsing multiple sources of information, that I describes in details in one of my previous posts. The Similarity Network Fusion (SNF) also belongs to this type of approach. Another approach would be explicitly model the individual data distributions and combining them as a joint probability using Bayes rule. Finally, one can try to extract common variation (i.e. disentangle the technology-specific and shared variation in the data) and factor it (split into orthogonal components) for better interpretation, a way used by PLS, CCA and Factor Analysis.

Graph based data integration belongs to the first approach from the previous section, i.e. when having been converted into graphs, the individual data sets represent pairwise connections between data points without any “memory” of what statistical process generated the individual data sets. In the graph space, it is straightforward to find an intersection between individual graphs from individual data sets by keeping edges consistently present between the data points across the graphs from individual data sets. The strength of this approach is that one can apply an appropriate distance metric when converting the raw data into graphs, i.e. working with binary data one might want to use the Hamming distance to compute pairwise connections between data points, while working with continuous data it might be sufficient to apply the Euclidean distance.

To demonstrate the idea of graph based data integration, we will apply it to the scNMT single cell Omics data set that comprises: 1) gene expression (scRNAseq), 2) DNA methylation (scBSseq), and 3) open chromatine region (scATACseq) information from the same biological cells. We will start with reading scNMTseq data, that is scRNAseq, scATACseq and scBSseq, filtering the data, e.g. by removing lowly expressed genes in the scRNAseq, applying log-transform to make the data look more normally distributed, and checking the data distributions.

The single cell gene expression (scRNAseq) data is somewhat zero-inflated and clearly continuous, so it might even be appropriate to compute pairwise similarities between the cells using Euclidean distance. However, when we plot scBSseq and scATACseq data distributions, it is clear that they follow a bimodal distribution, therefore it would not be appropriate to use Euclidean distance to measure similarity between cells using this type of rather binary data. Therefore we will use Hamming distance for scBSseq and scATACseq, while Dice and Jaccard similarity might be a possible choice as well.

If we look at the scBSseq data matrix, the elements seem to vary between 0% and 100% implying that a certain CpG site can be methylated (100%) or un-methylated (0%). In reality, not all elements of the matrix are strictly either 0% or 100%, this might be due to technical sampling and sequencing reasons. However, with a good certainty one can treat the scBSseq data (the same is valid for scATACseq data as well) as binary data. To make the data explicitly binary, we will code all counts below 50% as 0 and above 50% as 1. A similar binarization procedure is then applied to the scATACseq data. You do not have to do it this way, but for the sake of explaining methodology, it is interesting to demonstrate how continuous data, scRNAseq, can be integrated with fully binary data, scBSseq and scATACseq, using graph intersect approach.

Now, we will construct a KNN graph using the raw gene expression data from the scRNaseq data set. We will apply Euclidean similarity metric between the cells and keep 30 nearest neighbors for each cell. In fact, when starting with a fully-connected graph, the KNN method in scikit-learn will check the weights for the edges of each pair of data points, and select 30 neighbors with largest weights for each data point. As a result, we will get a KNN adjacency matrix, where 1 means cells are connected and 0 means disconnected. To learn other tricks of graph construction please check this wonderful notebook from Rui Benfeitas.

Here we selected a random pair of points, e.g. ESC_F04 and ESC_F07, that seem to be connected in the scRNAseq data set. We will track this connection in the scBSseq and scATACseq data sets. Below we will visualize the KNN graph using the MDS layout, and highlight the connection between ESC_F04 and ESC_F07 cells by red edge. We already now can observe some sort of clustering of ESC cells and EB cells separately from each other. Now, we will do the same graph construction for the scBSseq data, for details please check complete jupyter notebook. In this case, since scBSseq is a binary data, it is not optimal to measure similarity between cells with the Euclidean distance as we did for scRNAseq data. Here we choose the Hamming distance, although Dice and Jaccard distances might also be appropriate for categorical/binary data.

Great! Now we have constructed 3 KNN graphs from scRNAseq, scBSseq, and scATACseq and ready to intersect the graphs. The idea of graph intersection, as it beautifully demonstrated in Wolfram Math World public resource, is to keep edges consistently present across multiple scOmics data sets. We will use the intersection function implemented in the igraph library. Some nodes are going to be isolated after we have performed the graph intersection. Here, for simplicity, we are going to ignore/delete those nodes and not consider them as separate clusters later when running Leiden graph-based clustering.

Let us visualize the consensus graph obtained by intersecting the 3 graphs from separate scOmics and demonstrate that the connection/edge between ESC_F04 and ESC_F07 cells is still present, we will highlight this edge by red. Now we can run the Leiden graph-based clustering algorithm (modification of Louvain algorithm), that finds 4 clusters present on the consensus graph.

We can see that the EB cells seem to form a separate (green) cluster, while the ESC cells are now split into at least two (blue and red) clusters. There is a minor group of yellow cells that was found by Leiden to be the fourth cluster, but this probably should be tuned with the resolution parameter of the Leiden algorithm as the yellow cells do not seem to visually stand out as a separate cluster. On the other hand, this might also be an issues with the layout. Trying another graph layout could possibly demonstrate that the yellow cells indeed form a distinct cluster.

It turns out that the manual KNN graph construction followed by intersection of the graphs from individual scOmics, the way we did in the previous section, is not really necessary as this option seems essentially included into the UMAP dimension reduction algorithm. Indeed, as it is stated in the original UMAP article:

Making use of the fuzzy simplicial set representation of data UMAP can potentially be extended to support dimension reduction for datasets with heterogeneous data types. Each data type can be seen as an alternative view of the underlying structure, each with a different associated metric, for example categorical data may use Jaccard or Dice distance, while ordinal data might use Manhattan distance. Each view and metric can be used to independently generate fuzzy simplicial sets, which can then be intersected together to create a single fuzzy simplicial set for embedding.

Therefore, UMAP allows for fast construction of the fuzzy simplicial sets (that is similar to building KNN graphs) of individual scOmics data sets and their intersection with just a few lines of code, see the interesting discussion about mixing different data types with UMAP here.

To demonstrate how UMAP can be used for integrating scOmics data, we will intersect graphs from single cell RNAseq and protein level data sets from 8617 blood mononuclear cells (CBMCs) sequenced by the CITE-seq technology, we are going to produce a consensus scOmics UMAP plot. Again, the idea is to convert the two scOmics data sets into the non-parametric graph space (fuzzy simplicial sets) where they forget their technological differences, and intersect the graphs in this non-parametric space. The resulting consensus / integration graph is going to be used for constructing the UMAP embeddings.

However, we are going to start with displaying UMAP embeddings for the two individual scOmics data sets. As an optimal number of nearest neighbors we will choose sqrt(N) = sqrt(8617) = 93, the motivation behind this choice was covered here and has something to do with an optimal size of a random walk on a lattice, beyond this size the “memory” of the random walk is lost.

The colors on the UMAP dimension reduction plots correspond to the 12 cell populations of the blood mononuclear cells (CBMCs). Now we will construct the intersection of the two graphs / fuzzy simplicial sets, and visualize the resulting embeddings.

In the resulting embedding plot, from intersecting the two scOmics, one can make a few interesting observations. For example, the gray cluster, that was previously homogeneous on the scRNAseq UMAP plot, splits into three sub-clusters. On the other hand, the previously indistinguishable on the scRNAseq UMAP plot purple cell population forms now a distinct cluster separated from the blue cells. Both results seem to be driven by including the protein level information into the resulting consensus UMAP embeddings.

In this article, we have learnt that graph-based data integration represents an interesting way of combining multiple sources of information for boosting the accuracy of an analysis. Converting the raw data into non-parametric graph space with appropriate individual similarity metrics allows for keeping only pairwise connection information while omitting the technology-specific noise in the data. The following intersection of the graphs (or fuzzy simplicial sets in UMAP terminology) provides straightforward visualization and evaluation of the data integration. UMAP seems to be ideally suited for data integration as it allows for the specification of individual distance metrics and the intersection of the graphs, i.e. mixing heterogeneous data, with just a few lines of code.

In the comments below, let me know which analytical techniques from Life Sciences seem especially mysterious to you and I will try to cover them in the future posts. Check the codes from the post on my Github. Follow me at Medium Nikolay Oskolkov, in Twitter @NikolayOskolkov and do connect in Linkedin. In the next post, we will cover how to cluster in UMAP space, stay tuned.
